Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom

us1iDiZPnIjtJgBcInvzmQ.text: We came on a Saturday and had to wait over an hour, but the cocktails at the bar were delicious, and the wait passed quickly. This is one of the few places I can go as a vegetarian and find too many menu options to choose from. I ate until I was stuffed, and everything was wonderful.

qVl77xMQXX3mI-E-lrwDRQ.text: Loved everything about this place!!! Cute and intimate atmosphere, reasonable prices, and AMAZING food! Can't wait to go back!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Gyoza!
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Seoul bowl salad!
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Thought I ordered the classic burger but it looked like the beetroot burger so I'm not sure which one it was  either way it was amazing!!!

6EhDE6V7aRMzViID-CaQjw.text: I came here for my birthday meal with my friend, I wasn't fond of the no booking policy, but the cocktail menu was fab, we drank Turkish roses while we waited, and nibbled on the olives which were lovely.We were sat down after a reasonable wait, and found it hard to pick from the lovely menu. The tables were fairly close together, *insert celebrity name drop here* knocked a karafe of water over with his bum- but, if there were less tables, it would take even longer to get one! I ate the halloumi burger with sweet potato fries whilst sipping on an elderflower martini (you might have figured I like gin and floral flavours by now!) it was beautiful, and the Harissa added a nice kick. We had a particularly lovely lady server, who was fab. After that we had puddings, pecan pie and the polenta cake, the polenta cake in particular, was a ruddy dream, and we recommended this to *celebrity name drop*, and he agreed. The reason I haven't given them 5* is due to the little downer at the end- the added 12.5?% (I think, it might have been 15%) gratuity, with a note saying you can ask for it to be removed OF COURSE WE ARENT GOING TO ASK, WE'RE AWKWARD AND BRITISH!!! This is one step on pet hates behind handing the man the bill, especially when I'm paying- we genuinely would have tipped more than that- but I'm like a petulant child when it comes to showing my appreciation, I don't want to be told I have to do anything!!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Turkish roses!!

KvqH8VcgclCRz3gnB5lCFg.text: Possibly the best vegan restaurant I've ever tried. I had the mixed stir fry vegetables with brown rice. The dish was absolutely mouth watering with the perfect mixture of my favourite veggies and the most flavourful seasoning. My other friends had burgers and a curry, all of which they seemed to enjoy. The aperol was also good, though slightly more alcoholic than other ones that I've tried. Ambience was small and cozy. Not the most spacious of venues, but it added to the atmosphere and personality.Lastly, service was good. Not the most attentive with regular check-in's or anything, but they knew when to come take our orders, serve the food, bring the desserts menu and bring the bill. I would absolutely go back!

6et3zcInFwX_-HmwaExgRg.text: I'm not a veggie, but happily open to the concept. The reality at Mildred's is fantastic. OK, the space is a little cramped and you can't make a reservation unless you're a large party. But the menu options are numerous and delicious. I had a tough time deciding but eventually chose the veggie stir fry. My portion was enormous and I loved the contrasting textures of crunchy greens and cashews with the soy-soaked tofu and brown rice. My companions also hoovered up their veggie burrito and risotto. Alas, we were all too stuffed for dessert. Although truth be told, they didn't look that exciting. Sugar-free choc torte - say whaat?The bill came to £64 for three mains and four drinks. Not great value when you consider there's no meat involved but then the quality was outstanding. I'd definitely be up for visiting Mildred's again.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. The glorious veggie stir-fry

zGm97ImG9Ir-9x7kKudMbA.text: What a great vegan spot! Lots of salad options as well as comfort foods. The must get here is the polish beetroot burger. Sounds strange, but this thing packs a flavor punch. We got it with Vegan cheese and the sweet potato fries. This place does get quite crowded, so be there early or make a reservation. I would not say it's a great place for large groups.

xvuYjcA85KZXhXwp0_FZ_A.text: Im not a vegan but the food was amazing. It was my first experience eating vegan. A friend and I went at 6pm it was quite busy. We waited for 15 mins although they said it would be 30. We ordered the dumplings and avocado and the curry as a main dish. Oh wow! They were good. Quite cramped inside and little space left to move around.

dQb9lU45hXu9-2-VpaY9YA.text: I'm not vegan or vegetarian but would happily eat here again and again. Shared two starters and two mains and all were excellent. Hummus well made, soul bowl would have again, and burrito was great too. Services very good. Able to get a table at lunch time though was busy with good turnover. Happy with food, service, and cost. Would recommend

gjsC1Abr-Rpo0o7PJftNuw.text: Food is good. But the restaurant is very noisy and crowded. Far too many people crowded into a small, narrow space. The bar selection had some good organic spirits but was extremely limited. The wait staff was pleasant but at the end we waited a lot time for our bill. As a long time vegan who has visited many good vegan restaurants in lots of cities I would not recommend Mildred's.

M1KGpZv0eq8FHC9A3-PAPg.text: Having waited 30mins for a table, Mildreds had much to answer for. Turns out the decor is wooden, simple and rustic and the service was a little sparse at times. Unfortunately they were not able to serve any fresh juices on the day I visited. Nevertheless the food itself was genuinely very agreeable. To a meat-eater, an indicator of good vegetarian food is when you don't even feel that there is anything missing from the meal i.e. there is no void left from having not consumed meat.The Mexican platter was an array of delights; everything from the soft warm black beans, the crunchy corn chips, the delightfully sour cream dip, and the chunky guacamole to the mango, brie and jalapeño quesadilla seemed fresh, appetising and prepared with a touch of pride. The variety of mains on the menu is equally impressive with an abundance of creative recipes giving you the age-old dilemma of what to choose. I eventually opted for the stir fried Asian vegetables (in shitake mushroom sauce with garlic, ginger, fresh chilli and coriander, served with organic brown rice, tofu and toasted cashews). This was a masterful creation; the abundance of ingredients work very well together to produce a mixture of flavours and textures and a very filling as well as balanced dish. In short all the food was attractive, served in pristine fashion and thoroughly satisfying. To be honest I can't quite put my finger on what it is missing that places it just shy from perfection in my mind, but I sense that in totality the restaurant could do with some refinement in interior design, staffing, its booking system (or lack thereof), and its choice of china and cutlery as well as a little bit of originality; little things that can make a difference but often go unnoticed. But have no doubt, Mildreds is a treasure trove of a vegetarian restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Sunblushed tomato, mozzarella and basil risotto cake
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. The Specials pasta
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Sri Lankan sweet potato and cashew nut curry

2ejjl_u1KVZYOzCJmxf5Mg.text: I had my list of vegan restaurants to visit while I London. Mildred's was at the top of my list. This place was super crowded. I waited about 15 minutes just to sit at the counter. I wouldn't let the line detract you from entering; the food is totally worth it. The menu listed vegan and gluten free options. I went all out and ordered a 3 course meal. The summer rolls were amazing light and flavorful. The curry had a lovely presentation and the flavors of the sweet potato blended well coconut milk and cashews. The brownie with ice cream was like chocolate heaven. This place seemed like a great spot for a date or small dinner party. They had a creative cocktail list which also makes it nice for drinks. The atmosphere was trendy: lots of solo diners with cool playlist in the background.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Sweet potato cashew curry
Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. Summer rolls

Qx-KIEukAuFTSqcFbR_7LQ.text: Love this Vegan/VG restaurant!! The food and service was exceptional!! We would definitely recommend this spot to ALL of our friends!!

Hv_6nVHqg62xW_TDoPexDA.text: LOVE this place!!! As a vegan, it is so refreshing and... relaxing to be able to walk into a restaurant and not have to worry about having to completely customize a meal to my lifestyle. The menu is quite lengthy, with lots of options for everyone. However, the wait time is typically pretty long no matter what time of day it is, so make sure you bring your patience, as it is quite a tight space to be in as well. Overall, I wish I could eat here every day.

YDL7z9K4eYZDmtYc0lGvuA.text: Friend from London recommended this place.Good food, drinks and vibe!The place was packed when we got there (Friday night).We had to wait for a bit, about 30 mins. Totally worth it, you can wait at the bar having 5* cocktails or other non-alcoholic drinks.The food is awesome with pretty reasonable price.

kqLlgof6TzPcLDUvu_kUnw.text: Had a really nice meal here. It was pretty packed so had to share a table but that's OK. Liked the atmosphere. Food was great for the most part. Really good Gyoza appetizer and awesome fried Haloumi cheese. The veggie burger however was a bit disappointing and my bf's burrito was inordinately spicy. Also loved the drinks. They serve alcohol and I had the Porn Star which was fantastic. The elderberry soda (non-alcoholic) was really delicious as well!

P-H-bWGYlivmuimiVGuBcw.text: Happenstance diner stop recommended by hotel Ham Yard. Have now been three times on a single visit to their different locations. Obviously loving  the food and the atmosphere... and drinks. Family of three vegetarians. Plenty of gluten free options too. Fresh and delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom

kQn-FhQE2pd5peItR0a8Ug.text: The first couple of times I ate here with my best friend who is vegetarian, the food would have got 4 stars. I had a very tasty sweet potato curry. I agree with all the other reviewers about the lack of space and the wait for a table. My opinion of Mildred's dropped slightly when the same friend had her Birthday party in the upstairs dining room. I loved the room and the tittilating photographs (no-one else amongst the party seemed to really notice these - what does that say about me?) but I was underwhelmed by my meal on this occasion. Perhaps the kitchen struggled to cope with such a large party?

z-sxZ_1njuq7BJonjj8Jtg.text: As mildreds is just around the corner from my work,I've been loads and it never disapoints! ,all my veggie friends demand on going whenever they come to visit.and I never feel outdone by not having any meat on my plate!  it's small and always busy but don't let that put you off, you can wait at the bar and have a organic ginger beer,if your not veggie this is still a great place to try, it's not all beans and pulses,.. they also cater for 'wheat free' and everything is explained on the menu,its not overpriced and the portions are really genorous but make sure you leave room for the cheescake!  They also do take away and in the day time also have a cafe 2 doors down. what you waiting for :)

5LZ6BlXpRExRu5hEVKDyRw.text: please also seehungryinlondon.com/2010/…  Mildreds is my favourite (cheap) vegetarian restaurant in London. I once in the while go there on weekends, after I had maybe a couple of drinks too many and loads of heavy food the day (the week?) before, for some small detoxing/feeling better about my body food (it's by far better than sports :) ). What I also like about it is, that it is not one of those annoying 'into your face vegetarian all meat eaters are bad' places but just happens to serve vegetarian food. so what. At my last visit I had delicious hummous and babaganoush (5.75) served with flat bread. The hummous perfectly creamy, the babaganoush very nicely seasoned with the distinct flavour of smoked aubergine and the flat bread crispy and fresh. There was no fault at all with this dish. Then the all important detoxing with the organic energising detox salad (7.00). I love this salad, I must have had it 10 times already: a full plate of crunchy carrots, fennel, different sprouts, fresh coriander, sultanas and pumpkin seeds with a lime-ginger dressing (I usually like to add some chilli sauce, then it's even more perfect). It tastes so fresh and moreish while being so healthy, sometimes this kind of food just hits the spot. Mildreds has daily changing specials, usually some soup, some vegetarian burger and a pasta dish and dessert. Regarding the desserts: even though I have never eaten any of them myself (I told you  detoxing!), they look absolutely amazing (and the people eating them look very happy). The staff is young, pleasant and nice to chat to and even though I have never been there for dinner, I would rather regard it as a lunch place, maybe not quite romantic date material (unless you want to impress a vegetarian of course!)

tveflwiSH8XAbfgzsdm73A.text: Great location, nice atmosphere, too much salt! This restaurant/cafe is in a great central location to meet a friend and have a quick and cheap veggie bite to eat. I thought the staff were friendly enough but lacked charm. I was a little dissapointed in the food as it was overpoweringly salty and the flavours were competing to heavily with each other.

wN_LeKENzMOIR4cBjKzfuw.text: Mildreds is a small, independent veggie restaraunt deep in the heart of Soho, but a rarity in central London as they have a private dining room available upstairs to hire, with no surcharge. The dining room is kitted out with sensual, smutty artwork which makes a delicous change! Food is above average vegetarian fare - highly recommended is the deep fried camembert, if your arteries can cope with it. Delicious artichoke salads and deserts. Wine and liquor is all organic, ensuring less hangovers! Delicious, and good for group bookings.

T9oha-_MI9OlkeyI00nUTw.text: One of my girlfriend's favourite restaurants in London, that manages to make interesting vegetarian food that appeals to meat-eaters and veggies alike. Our best experience there is still Valentines two years ago, when we had the most incredible mushroom and pancake gateau! Normally, you can't book, and you just have to hope for the best. But have a drink while you wait, and the food definitely justifies it.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom

E9kmJLHL3OVPSJmUEnCANg.text: Where do you take a vegan to eat when the very notion of 'no meat', 'no cheese', 'is it cooked in butter?', 'soy milk please' rules out most of the restaurants in Soho? Mildreds offers fresh and tasty, and reasonably priced (£80 for four, with drinks and entrees - no wine mind you) vegetarian and vegan fare in a relaxed atmosphere. The food is varied and tasty enough to convert even the most die hard carnivore.

1v_1VJ21QFwCcKRj9ZfX3g.text: I love Mildred's, if it was a bigger that would be great as it is always so busy when I go.  The food is fantastic and great variety (Not just burgers) Service is ok, and the seating isn't the best but when you get such great food you can't really complain.  This is definitely a restaurant I regularly attend and would highly suggest going to.

GzZps_Vzc7uzjUqZ4ljgJw.text: Sweet potato fries were good.  Cocktails were well-made.  Good atmosphere, but you'll wait to find a table.

GNrAZEf1K2YqoWZRd7Q2mw.text: i'm still thinking about the green curry i had to leave in my friend's fridge because we had to come back to the states.  mmm...sure would love to finish it now!  this adorable little place was something a dear friend of ours mentioned often during our stay in london, so it was fitting that our last meal was here.  lucky enough they were open until 11, or we wouldn't have been able to make it.  the menu was plentiful and i had a difficult time deciding, everything looked great.  we got a bottle of wine and we all enjoyed our dishes.  i got the dessert to go because it was past closing time.  we never felt rushed though.  i can't remember what i ordered for dessert, but when we got it back to our friend's place and opened up another bottle of wine, i dove into it.  some sort of chocolate shell with soft chocolate inside...amazing!  vegan!london is cool and i have always liked it, but the food options just may inspire us to figure out a way to live there!  mildred's is definitely on that list.

Ffzzjo2wTfX9Mu7HyV8rwQ.text: This place was packed on a Friday night! We took a recommendation we read to come after 9pm, and still waited 30-40 minutes for a seat. Was fine though. We just stood at the bar and had a drink. The tables are close together, so it's not somewhere you want to go for an intimate date, but it's not uncomfortable. We ordered some delicious hummus and baba ganoush as a starter, and for the mains we had the bangers and mash and the Ethiopian stew. As dessert the chocolate red currant brownie. We didn't leave raving about the food, but it was definitely good. What I liked about it was that they serve vegetarian versions of "real food". Contrary to other reviews we'd read, the service was friendly enough and quick with our orders.

7N4KjSjnOFNAwWUtbCyZKg.text: Very tasty, interesting vegetarian food. I went at 3 PM, and the place was empty. No waiting equals a happy me.

umOtKJGGoRdh9wpC6xPXQA.text: This restaurant is a real gem in London for vegans/vegetarians. The food here is really good, and has multiple options for vegans, gluten free, wheat free, or just regular vegetarians. The veggie burger was killer, and the sweet potato fries were the best I've ever had.

i_mqTnen77ca4ITdlTOVDg.text: Yet another review of Mildred's is surely testament to it's popularity. Heaving most days of the week and so frustrating that you can't book. Time it right in your arrival you must otherwise it's 'a half hour to 45 minute wait' and left to stand with drinks in hand in the bar/entrance that doubles as the holding pen you will be. Lucky little me I know three of the staff that work here so I'm often through the door to take the weight off my feet and have a cup of coffee mid afternoon when things aren't quite as crazy: between services. So biased I may be but I do think this is a great little place. The atmosphere is friendly and energetic while still allowing for a relaxing meal, the restaurant area is flooded with light during daylight hours from the glazed panels in the roof and the food never takes long to arrive. And and and, thank goodness they understand about decent sized portions for your bucks. Long gone are the days of worthy vegetarian restaurants where the menu was uninspiring and limited to nutroast or nutroast. Mildred's menu has dishes inspired from all corners of the globe but best in my opinion is still the mushroom and porchini pie. Where's the gravy? Inside. It's good.

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom

KW8d-ZYIDkhGk6wRnqPQyQ.text: I've visited several times and the food is usually reasonably good. Service is not its strong point and can be lacking and even unfriendly. Which makes its 12.5% 'optional' service charge hard to stomach. A pity.

Fmxz5oDPmkwvv6tvpOdSkw.text: I'm definitely not a vegetarian, but I had to try out Mildred's after hearing so much good stuff about it (plus, they do takeaway and I used to live 'round the block).  I was very pleasantly surprised.  First, it's got a great, buzzing atmosphere due to its popularity (be prepared to wait).  Secondly, the menu is extensive and includes interesting dishes that would appeal to veggies and meaties alike (risotto cake? chickpea tagine? sweet potato curry? yes, please).  Third, I really liked my burger - and never even tried to compare it to a beef burger because it's just a different food altogether (it was creative, crunchy and fresh).  Finally, feeling virtuous, I happily enjoyed many glasses of organic white wine.

SPJqewE2Lt42LmGzzv1kGA.text: I love the atmosphere at Mildred's. It's warm, busy, hip and very inviting. The food is very good as well.  The menu has a great selection of original vegetarian dishes, moderately priced. We waited about 45 minutes to an hour for a table and  were not disappointed.  Having the option of drinks at the bar while waiting is a big plus.

Gdb5erFWMZuN5r5Ry9h3HA.text: The food was wonderfull, the atmosphere was great and the staff are good looking and quirky!

dJeqsTN0UItXblszo0mbyA.text: Really tasty veggie food that would definitely appeal to non-veggies. It gets really, really busy (which is always a good sign) but as they don't take bookings you have to get there early for a seat. I had a really good burrito but my definite fave was the sweet potato fries which I kept pinching from my friends plate, yum.

nKbhsQ6JkLWaH1gbjRpM-w.text: Came in during busy hour, but the wait wasn't long at all. Had great wine in lively fun bar while we waited. Service was really nice and all options well marked vegan. Excellent appetizers, entrees, desserts. Excellent meal with local but vegetarian favorites from start to finish.

BQiYhsbS6DtxjpBac5caQA.text: Having recently visited the West Coast of the US and having a huge selection of vegetarian restaurants with expansive menus, I was a little disappointed in the small selection of items.However, the price was right and my food was very, very good, with some items bordering on amazing. We had two starters - beets with feta that was so-so in flavor but high marks for presentation and freshness. The other starter was a ricotta mushroom ravioli with a porcini sauce (ther was a sage butter option for these ravioli as well, but I was SOO happy with the delectable porcini sauce!)I had the mushroom-ale pie with minty peas and some substantial thick-cut fried potato wedges. The mushroom pie was smoky, woodsy, rich, meaty - in a superb and delicate flaky crust akin to phyllo - also with a very nice presentation...really the highlight of my meal. The peas definitely on this side of yum. The fries a bit soggy, but certainly ranked above edible (it's hard to make good fries). Service was prompt and friendly, although not super attentive (they forgot to replace our forks and it took a while to get someone's attention - a forgivable mistake though not terribly high level). I'd recommend Mildreds for any vegetarians (or part-time vegetarians such as myself) as a solid and reliable dinner spot with interesting and flavorful dishes.

PHRLjgEDOajJ-P7vaUijIw.text: I am kind of torn between 3 and 4 stars here - on the one hand, I quite liked the busy and laid-back diner-style atmosphere, and I certainly left the place feeling very satisfied (if not to say stuffed). Yet, although the food was quite good, it didn't quite make the cut for saying "I'm a fan". I think I liked my appetizer best (artichoke crostini with vegan mayonaise), but the main (burger of the day) was rather average, and the sweet potato fries that I thought I had to try given that everyone seems to love them were good, but not outstanding. The dessert (chocolate truffle) was delicious again, but ultimately I was just a wee bit disappointed by the food (the main in particular). I also think that the service could definitely be better - our waiter was charming enough, but at the same time seemed distracted and not really interested in his job. The lacklustre service notwithstanding, they do make a point of adding an "optional" service charge of 12.5% to the bill (are we approaching American conditions here now?), which I definitely think is not cool.So all in all we had a pleasant evening, and the food was good, but it wasn't to fall in love with, and with the service being what it was I can't give more than 3 stars.

T0c6wvEdo3Vs3_1CA3Isjw.text: It's in Soho so it's obviously going to be more expensive than some, but the food is tasty and plentiful, the staff are friendly (if a bit rushed) and they have a modest cocktail menu. A bit slapdash in an endearing way, and great for an evening out with friends  the choice and variety of food was so good we were eating off each others' plates all night!

-FrIHAokLVBeuhNvwhXlSg.text: I've visited twice, once for lunch and another time for dinner. For lunch my girlfriend and I had the stir-fry with tofu and the duck wrap with a ginger chocolate "pudding" as dessert.The dinner meal included the dishes of the day: creamed legume soup, mushroom veggie pasta, and apple/rhubarb crumble. The soup blew my mind. The pasta had too much pasta and not enough veggies. The crumble was worth the 9-day wait I had to endure between visits to taste it. YUM.Girlfriend LOVED the place. Cha-ching!

QedNMKBrSM_Y4sVnpp9n2g.text: Bustling and cute atmosphere. Service is friendly but not so quick or attentive. The food menu is extensive and creative, but it didn't quite do it for me. Perhaps we just chose the wrong things but the sausage and mash was just ok, and the Ethiopian stew was alright. I did enjoy the homemade bread and olives (hard to go wrong there!). I feel like they could do the food better, with more flavor.

ev_4Z0uURI0zQgjSMxWWnw.text: Oh Mildred, what can I say that hasn't already been said? Your Sweet Potato fries are worth the journey alone and you actually make your veggie burgers rather than buying frozen soy patties. The risotto cakes, your soups, the sage butternut squash ravioli, in fact I would gladly eat anything on your menu. Well except for that green Thai curry dish. Let's be honest, you kind of mailed it in on that one... and I do have to say I was pouty when you replaced the raspberries in your flourless dark chocolate cake with oranges. Am I the *only* person who things dark chocolate and orange is a bad idea?Still, you are easily one of my London favorites. At a similar price point to Eat and Two Veg, frankly Mildred, it isn't even close. I've taken a number of non veggie guests to you and everybody loves it. In fact, my parents are coming to visit again in October, guess where they want to eat again? My mom even remembered your name; Mildred, *that* is saying something.You do get busy for dinner most nights and always on the weekend evenings, which sometimes lead to slow service. I hate to wait, but for you, I will. And what is this whole waiter attitude thing I'm reading about, because you always treat me right. Mildred, you can tell me, am I your favorite? (Ah, I knew it!)Even if some other Yelpers haven't been showing you the love here recently, I'm here to let you know that you are 6 stars in my book.

UtK5acXSSIqkR4zTrA9vzA.text: I have been eating in Mildred's for years and even had the first date with my wife in there. I am not vegetarian but I love the food and the service. Always worth a visit if you are in Soho.

LdNhZGgewWQ_amWOb7VyRQ.text: The food here was very good. I had the stir fry which when it arrived looked to be mostly broccoli, and as a meat eater I was doubtful it would fill me up. However, on starting I discovered a mountain of tofu and other good stuff and struggled to finish the whole thing (because of the volume, I really wanted to eat it all as it was great!)When we went it was really busy so we had to wait a while for our table, then our order to be taken and then the food, but it was worth it in the end. I wouldn't go here on a date though, the tables were really close together and it felt crowded.

sibUwa54QlJBPPzNoIyvHA.text: Love, love, LOVE Mildred's! I can't speak highly enough about the place! My flatmate and I (both vegetarians) make it our go-to spot for girl nights and are never disappointed. The food is delicious and the service is stellar. The sweet potato fries are a staple -- heavenly! Definitely a great place to hit up in Soho for vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike!

IVvtW-4naPuW7QcFYeDPsA.text: Decent veggie place. I was not too impressed by the waiters, with impatient slightly snobbish attitudes. On top of which they automatically add 12.5% tip to your bill. I you can get past all that, the food is quite good. I am a fan of their appetizer dumplings. I can go for a second round of those dumplings right now! The main course is average, but the nice decor makes this restaurant a decent place to visit.

vZNUmkxxUzGnQ337uXn9Dw.text: I should love this place.  I'm a vegetarian and this should be my mecca.  Right in the heart of Soho is this cool, stylish vegetarian eatery with food that is usually very good.  The sweet potato fries with sour cream are great to share... and the burrito is one of the best I've had in London.  However, there's a drawback here for me, and it's a biggie.  Mildred's doesn't take reservations.  So many times I've showed up here with mates and we've had to wait for what feels like an eternity.  The staff let you squeeze into the seats in the front with a glass of wine to sip, but it's crowded and noisy and so unattractive.  Plus seeing the food whiz by to the seated patrons can be tortuous when you're there on an empty stomach.  Grrr, I should have never written this review.  Can't get those sweet potato fries out of my head.  Any chance you'd wait in queue for me if I share my fries?

KqjpufXgVHMui2jzObxIdg.text: Always good to find a vegetarian restaurant as it's so nice to have more than two dishes to choose between on the menu. The food we ordered was good but expensive for what it was. The waiting list system is annoying. You can't book a table and having been told we would have to wait 45 mins for a table we were not allowed to go elsewhere for a drink. This wouldn't be a problem if there was somewhere to sit while you wait but there's only a tiny amount of standing room, which was already packed with other people on the waiting list. Service was fine and friendly, but the other factors bring it down to 3 stars. There are better veggie places in Brighton and they manage to cope if you leave and come back when your table is ready.

JtWR-1aCOaz7EalVMOxGkg.text: I dragged my other half here as part of my 'detox' vegan-esqe diet. I knew when he was happy it was obviously a good place. The food is all sold to you in an appealing way, unlike many other vegetarian/vegan places which try to make there food into something it is not. I went for the 'sausages' and celeriac mash, although there was less mash and more cabbage to my liking, and my partner had mushroom and ale pie (he even forgot there was no meat in it). The chocolate & raspberry torte was to die for, it says it was a vegan, but tasted so much like the real thing it was had to believe. This place does get packed quickly, and as you can not book you can make use of the bar (which is fully stocked with organic wines and beers as well as smoothies). At around 7-8 quid per main it was not a bad price. Would definetely return, even if i wasn't 'being vegan'.

E_cELiu3hjlfivCP-Vt4lQ.text: Vegetarian food, tasty and fresh with daily specials. Nice wine. Casual and relaxed. Yes, staff can be a little brusque but mainly because it gets so busy. I lunch here regularly and thoroughly recommend it for vegetarians and non vegetarians (if you can persuade them to cross the threshold!).

xTpo7g3k4hYPiVlngiuMcQ.text: Vegetarian hamburgers are a challenge. Face it, a portobello mushroom slapped in between a sesame bun will just never compete. Mildred's does a good, wholesome burger with fresh chunky fries. The haloumi was nothing to sing and dance about.Sometimes I find the crowd here slightly pretentious - a bit like I am superior because I don't eat meat. Well yes what am I doing at Mildreds then? Okay all is forgiven. When feeling loving and compassionate toward the world, I can forgive the waiters' brusque impatience as the restaurant can get packed. It's always encouraging to see people moving towards a healthier way of life.

kMzY6IOLIeiRBhEkBlN1PA.text: On my numerous visits to Mildreds over the past few years I've enjoyed the tasty food, the wine, the extensive vegan options and even the notoriously offish waiting staff. I used to smile and tell funny tales about being served by sulky waitresses, pointing out to friends that as long as the food stayed good and came in a reasonable time I didn't care what mood the staff were in. It saves on tipping, right? Last time I went, however, the shine had dulled on my Mildreds experience . A group of six of us headed there for my birthday meal, arriving one by one over the space of about 20 minutes. There was plenty of space and I was assured we could definitely have a table, but that we'd have to wait until we had all arrived before we could sit down. This had happened to me before at Mildreds so I wasn't surprised, but as two of us, then three of us, then four, then five ended up standing in the crowded bar area at the front of the restaurant in full view of our empty, ready and waiting table I got more and more annoyed about the policy. Eventually I lied and said the last person couldn't make it just so we were allowed to sit down and look at the menuwhen she showed up 10 minutes later a waitress huffily brought her cutlery back. I'm not a silly teenager and don't really expect special treatment on my birthday from complete strangers, but let's just say the moody Mildreds staff failed to amuse me that night. However you feel about your customers, having a certain degree of respect for the fact that they are paying for the privilege of sitting and eating in your restaurant is surely a standard requirement, and appreciating that there are plenty of other places to choose to go to for friendlier, less uppity service on special occasions might make them try a bit harder to keep customers coming back. The one thing they have is the nice food, but it's not amazing enough for me to forget the rest. I've probably been to Mildreds about seven times over the past two years, but the way I feel about the place right now I couldn't tell you when or if I will be back. The churlish service compounded with recent information that their famed veggie burgers were made with Sosmix - a soya protein mix you can get in shops for about £2 - has really put me off. With so many other good places to eat in the vicinity I think I'm going to be giving miserable Mildreds a miss for a while at least.

yTqN0Zz9a-W6cyuGPhxEgw.text: As most people have said Mildred's is the sort of veggie restaurant that you'd be happy to take non veggies to. The vegetable stir fries are very filling by themselves but can be made even more so by adding Tofu. The last time I went I had a very satisfying mushroom and ale pie with mushy peas and chips. It made a great healthier veggie option to a steak and ale pie. Desserts, if you can fit them in, are fantastic. There's always a good fruity crumble with cream or custard and if you go when the meringue is on the menu, it's wonderful.

ynBefkiyWM7X_8omFNO6Vw.text: As a non-vegetarian, I can happily confirm that even non-veggies will love the food here. They do. I do. It is busy and it is small and it does feel kind of cramped and there's a very haughty waitressbutthe quality of the food makes up for all of that. Also of note is the private dining room, which you can book free of charge and is an elegant upstairs room decorated with some fine examples of Victorian pornography. Which is certainly a talking point. This room is perfect for a special occasion and I've never had a problem booking it.

rJIYb_a8e3xG0SG_bYHbfw.text: Seating is a bit cramped, but food is amazing! The burger and chips with basil mayo is yummy. We have been here thrice and have not yet had a bad service (touch wood).

LFhm1f8npSExERnXzdH8PQ.text: My husband and I had two great meals at Mildred's, after a good hour wait.  The food was very good, love not having to worry about the broth being meat.  Drinks good as well.  My problem with Mildred's is that the tables are really close together, and it was super noisy.  This was a Monday night!

idBq8hJ_e8uqSvI-JrZnhQ.text: Always love a bit of Mildreds. They have a no booking policy though (unless you have 10ppl + then they have a private dining area), so be prepared to wait.. 40mins to and hour+. Standard. Don't be fooled by the mirror at the far end of the restaurant, it doesn't actually have that many seats! So generally you have to wait at the bar after putting your name down with the maitre d. It can be very busy on a Friday night, we went on a Friday recently and there was already an hour long wait at 6pm with more people queueing. It can be pretty frantic and confusing if you've never been before though so be prepared, it's quite a narrow space and if you walk in you're kind of stuck in limbo between people trying to get a drink and getting to the MD to find out what's going on. I saw a poor American tourist that was trying to figure out how long the wait was so he did the natural thing and asked the closest staff member behind the bar, she rolled her eyes and very curtly told him she was bar staff and that he had to try and fight through to ask someone else. We thought the way she spoke was pretty rude. The food is pretty good for vegetarian though. Service can def be a bit better... even trying to order once sat, and trying to pay was a little bit of a mission. Plenty of staff on too so not sure what happened. Would give more stars but just thought the service was below par and ambience was too stressful. It's a shame because it used to be much better.

nTIqo1SP9i6eoZFfaIdTxg.text: Singapore Curry: (5 stars) perfect in every wayMushroom & Ale Pie: (3.5 stars) excellent veg version of hearty ale pie although mushy peas and chips were not the bestNOTE: It is significantly cheaper to take away and there is a lovely park around the corner.

xaszrT9X19hUgEAreX_JHA.text: I loved it, and even my non-vegetarian husband loved it.We went at about 6:20 on a Friday and had to wait 45-50 minutes outside, but it was worth it.The seating inside is a little tight, so you are less than a foot from the person next to you. We actually had a shares table, so my two person group shared a four person table with another two person group. It worked out totally fine since they were super nice (new friends!) but it could be close quarters for others.We had the dumplings appetizer. It was a little smaller than anticipated. But the flavour (especially sauce) was great. For mains, both the Sri Lankan bowl and Halloumi Burger had great flavour and were very decent sized portions for London. My favorite thing was the sweet potato fries, though. They were huge and perfect. Just perfect.

20RBdYnqfgQ_Ei8M2XhAEg.text: What a delicious meal we had at Mildreds. Found this place via Yelp as I am always in the quest for a good vegan restaurant. We did a day trip to London on our own while visiting my niece who is serving in the USAF stationed in England. For my husband's sake and to his pleasure the portions were very pleasing.  We started with a bowl of the sweet potato soup which was delicious. We each chose a different dish, but everything was perfectly seasoned and cooked!!  Small place so be prepared to rub shoulders with the next table but service was good and food came quickly.  The mushroom and ale pie was hearty and flavorful and my husband loved it. My daughter chose the black bean and red rice burrito, which stood up to any burrito from back home "across the pond". I had the Sri Lankan curry which we all agreed was tasty. Sorry no pics to share because the visual was equally appealing.

AqrLo1nKEVHuXARm8SSoDA.text: A vegetarian/vegan restaurant? Most people would scoff and be none too pleased to be brought here (that's if you could get in as the queues and wait list is quite hefty). You've got to suck it up and acknowledge there'll be no meat but it will be one of the tastiest meals ever. This is the most impressed I've been with a restaurant in a while! And although this isn't 5* food, as in Michelin */posh nosh, it certainly is 5* for what it is - amazing tasting, full of flavours, nice decor and vibe, friendly service and huge portions - really proving that meat isn't everything! Mildred's doesn't take bookings and as a walk in establishment you are guaranteed a wait. We (2 of us) arrived shortly after 5.30 on a Friday and popped our names on the waitlist with an estimated sit down time of 6. You have to wait at the restaurant so can't go anywhere else for a drink but they have a bar and places to perch (with only a few chairs outside). We found somewhere to lean and ordered two cocktails for the wait. At £7 they are reasonably priced. I got the rose and gin cocktail - very refreshing and would definitely order it again. Perching quite close to where the food was coming out meant we got to drool over that while perusing the menu ready for when we were seated (we were on a tight schedule as going to the theatre after). We were seated pretty much bang on 6 in the back of the restaurant - a lovely open, high, glass ceilinged spaced. It is very bright, modern and spacious throughout although some of the tables looked a bit squished together - we were lucky enough to have plennnnty of space as we had a few bags of shopping as well. There is also a downstairs however I have no idea what it is like! After ogling the burgers for 30 minutes, both my friend and I got their famous vegan burgers with the addition of Monterey Jack cheese (making them only veggie). They kindly brought out the vegan cheese for us to try as I was curious - cold it was grossss. I can see that once melted in the burger it would be a good alternative.  We also ordered sweet potato chips and corn chips with avocado as sides. The food came after about 15 minutes, which was reasonable but I was soooo hungry I barely managed a photo before I devoured it. Both burgers were so good, full of flavour, with a yummy brioche bun and a huge slice of tomato and crisp lettuce. The sweet potato chips were nice (a bit soggy which I love) and were served with an amazing chipotle ketchup and basil mayo. The corn chips were ok, nothing special but the guacamole was gooood (quite garlicky). One thing to note is the portions are huge! Each burger was £8 and sides about £4/5 but it is well worth it - I was so so full and satisfied. While we were finishing our mains a couple next to us were sharing the most decadent chocolate brownie I've ever seen. We were seriously tight for time and super full however after finding out the peanut brownie and ice cream was all vegan, and spotting some tasty sounding dessert cocktails, we asked if the waitress could rush our order through and also bring the bill. This she did with no problem and kept checking up on our drinks order for us - such good service. As promised we were out of there in time to catch our show (just!) but not before enjoying the tastiest brownie. The ice cream tasted so good that the lady next to us was demanding that it couldn't possibly be dairy free! The cocktails were also good especially the bourbon bomb however we didn't quite have the time to appreciate them. In total the bill came to just under £70 with service charge which although isn't cheap is brilliant for the amount of food, quality of food and service. This is why they deserve their 5*.I can't wait to come back (showing it off to other friends) to try the rest of menu - as well as the burgers they have a whole host of meals like curry, risotto cakes and stir fry that looked and smelled delish as well as other desserts like choco cake and orange cake.

ge0WJztwhkjZfy53Rby4Tg.text: I came here at 6:45p on a Wed night and there was an hr wait. They don't take reservations for 2 so that's the downside - however, it really is worth the wait. You can have a drink at the bar but the front area is bustling so there's not much room to hang out. My husband and I are vegan (and I'm GF) and there was an abundance of options. Everything is clearly labeled on the menu, the hardest thing will be deciding what to get. Service was good, every table was full and staff was really friendly. Food was truly excellent! From the apps to the large plates to dessert, we enjoyed every dish and left nothing behind. It was all really filling so come hungry. If we lived in London we'd be regulars but we'll be sure to tell all our friends to go, vegan or not!

sYER0F5LO_NFnJqvybFkqA.text: I cannot wait to go back to London to revisit Mildreds. I had the Sri Lankan curry and the beet salad. If it ain't broke don't fix it so I'm looking forward to having the same exact meal again. Everything about this dish was absolutely delicious. I have been back time and time again and i am NEVER disappointed. They have taken out the amazing beet salad so i have tried other appetizers and they are all delicious.I recently went to the Camden location, same great taste minus the line up!!!

AdTXqjpMbNygyQrVpzQV1g.text: The food is really good but nothing amazing. Certainly not worth over an hour wait. Some of the people who work here are really snooty as are a bunch of the people hanging around the bar and entrance. My particular waitress was nice though. I would rather go to a salad or Asian place with vegan options than here.

kICGFNKbZbj-9GwNUEuFDA.text: Luncha nd dinner are both excellent, but as this place has gotten popular lately, expect a wait. As others have said, the seating is "intimate".  The gyoza are great, the halloumi burger is excellent, and desserts are always fabulous so save room.  Even my meat-easting friends love it here.

7YLwC1dyWHCWW4uiRdrtAg.text: We got to Mildreds just in time to be seated without a wait. Started with the grilled halloumi which I had never tasted before but will be sure to look for in the States. The Polish burger was just right especially after I asked the waitress to substitute raw spinach for the iceburg lettuce. (Why eat white lettuce?) The accompanying fries were fine but not the best I've had (or seen). Great vegetarian place though and a long line of people waiting to eat by the time we left to go to theatre (6:30ish).

lDmqKC81zPeb_In0OqzlHQ.text: Nice food overall and good prices, but the staff.......Attitude, not nice, kind of rude to be honest, not helpful, bad jokes with attitude and fake smiles. Some work needs to be there.

ukvF5glzks1L0DvKYDcOPA.text: From the friendly host to the spectacular chips, Mildred's stole my heart from the get-go. New to London, it's splendor, and it's vegan scene,Mildred's immediately popped up when I searched vegan options in the area. Getting there was a mission, as my friend and I hopped on a bicycle-cart (don't know the name of this transportation mode off the top off my head) , and directed the rider using Yelp/Google Maps/my minimal common sense in getting about the area. After some missed turns and slight freak outs caused by the weather (us L.A folks don't do well in rain) and a tight schedule (fifteen hour layover in London for a first timer), we made it to Mildred's an hour short of closing.Greeted by a extremely outgoing and Chatty-Cathy host, we were told the wait would be about fifteen minutes. We didn't mind and made our way to the bar to charge our nearly deceased phones. I had already scoped the menu, so I had some options in mind, and the expo window, close to the bar, allowed me to see up close what my options looked like. Initially, I was sold on the Ale Pie with fries and mushy peas (there are hundred of reviews highlighting this dish, just scroll down), but after taking a look at the tofu-lentil burger with fries that were being delivered to tables, I went into contemplation. Once we were seated (the wait ended up being shorter than expected), the contemplation became a full-blown debate. The options! Only one night in London! The foodie in me was about to have a melt down! So I went with my gut (quite literally) and ordered the burger because the dipping sauce and fries paired it in a way that made it irresistible to ignore. My friend ordered a stir fry (he never does this--ever--I was shocked).The wait wasn't long at all (maybe ten minutes) and people watching for a newbie was a fun at its best during my wait. Our food arrives, we proceed to dig in (because the clock is ticking and London is waiting for us). The food was marvelous. Every--single--bite. The fries were everything London is known for if not more, the burger was so fresh tasting, the tofu and lentils perfectly balanced and creating a soft patty, and the sauce (an aioli or blue cheese of a sort) was divine. The same for the dipping sauce the fries were paired with. I was just way too happy with my selection. I tried a bite of my friend's dish and it was Asian-fusion at its finest. As I finish this review, I can't help but feel nostalgic and sad that I won't be back to Mildred's for what might be years. Oh well, at least I got to try it and it's amazing, vegan cuisine while in the U.K. This place is a gem that if in the states, I would be an avid regular of. A well earned five stars. Did I mention the host is awesome?

photos.caption: Photo of Mildreds - London, United Kingdom. The tofu-lentil burger with fries and an amazing dipping sauce. Loved it!

K14W70bYTV_tMH_heB7iIA.text: So one of my friends is on this new diet, and I had to find a place specific for her tastes - lo and behold Mildred's. It was one of the top searches when you look for vegetarian in London.I get there at around 7pm, they don't do reservations, and the place is heaving. I mean I had very little room to walk amongst others in the queue awaiting a table. Everyone's chatting, people are looking happy, the bar staff and the waiters are on the go constantly. Fortunately a half hour later we got a table (minus one star) and it was a shared table upstairs. The menu is straight forward - they have about 5 mains to select from, so you don't have to over think on decisions, I went for the tomato bean sausages with the mash and spinach, and it was delicious!!! They put these herbs in - I don't know what but it something similar to a wasabi kick! Also had cauliflower and sweet potato on the side - definitely recommend. My two other friends were loving it and we all agreed we would definitely come back. Unexpectedly - awesome. I love surprises.

YHDgCCpsszoR9cGTJQsFaA.text: Wow! Started with an incredibly nice & professional server named Angelica. I asked what is most popular, she answered all my questions and helped direct my scattered hungry brain.. I had the Grilled artichokes with cashew cream and grilled lemon. Holy smokes this is my new favorite thing! For my main I got the polish burger, it is a beet root and bean base which is a decently firm burger compared to many vegan patties. The herb mayo is really nice as well. I would definitely recommend this place without a doubt. Lastly, I ended with the chocolate hazelnut brownie w/ice cream. Very nice. Crumbly but not dry. A bit sweet but you expect that from this type of dessert. I will absolutely come back every time I'm in the area. And they do have some non vegan options for the picky eater!
